test_description: Verify a new user can successfully complete the entire registration, email verification, and initial login flow.
business_risk: Critical - A failure in this flow blocks all user acquisition.
preconditions: Staging environment is running with all services. A mail-trapping service is configured.
test_steps: 1. Navigate to the registration page. 2. Enter a unique, valid email and a password meeting complexity rules. 3. Submit the form. 4. Verify the success message is shown. 5. Check the mail-trap for the verification email. 6. Extract the verification link and navigate to it. 7. Verify the account activation success message. 8. Navigate to the login page. 9. Enter the new credentials. 10. Click login.
expected_result: User is successfully logged in and redirected to the main news feed. The user's account status in the database is 'active'.
test_data_needs: A unique, unused email address. A mail-trapping service API key.
environment_requirements: Staging environment with external network access for mail service.
success_criteria: 100% test pass rate. Flow completes in under 30 seconds.
failure_impact: Critical - Prevents new users from joining the platform.
data_setup_complexity: Low - Requires a new email for each run.
cleanup_requirements: Delete the created test user account after the test run.
security_considerations: Verification link must be single-use. Tokens should not be guessable.
performance_expectations: Each step should respond within NFR limits (e.g., <500ms).
accessibility_requirements: All forms and pages must be keyboard navigable and meet WCAG 2.1 AA.

test_description: Verify that an invalidated JWT (after logout) cannot be used to access a protected API endpoint.
business_risk: Critical - A session hijacking vulnerability could lead to full account compromise.
preconditions: Identity service and Redis are running. A protected endpoint (e.g., /profile/me) exists.
test_steps: 1. Send a POST request to the login endpoint with valid credentials to get an access token. 2. Store the access token. 3. Send a POST request to the logout endpoint using the access token. 4. Immediately send a GET request to a protected endpoint (e.g., /profile/me) using the same stored access token.
expected_result: The final GET request must be rejected with an HTTP 401 Unauthorized status code.
environment_requirements: Integration environment with backend services and Redis.
success_criteria: 100% of requests with blocklisted tokens are rejected.
failure_impact: Critical - Allows unauthorized access to user accounts after logout.
security_considerations: The JWT blocklist is the primary defense against token reuse.
performance_expectations: The blocklist check should add less than 5ms latency to requests.

test_description: Verify the P95 latency of the news feed API endpoint under nominal load.
business_risk: High - A slow feed is the primary cause of user dissatisfaction and churn.
preconditions: A dedicated performance environment exists. The environment is populated with a large, realistic dataset (100k users, 1M posts, 10M connections).
test_steps: 1. Ramp up virtual users over 5 minutes to 1000 concurrent users. 2. Each user makes a GET request to the feed API endpoint. 3. Sustain the load for 15 minutes. 4. Monitor P95 response time, error rate, and system resource utilization (CPU/Memory) of the feed service and Redis.
expected_result: The P95 latency of the feed API remains below 200ms throughout the test. The error rate is less than 0.1%. System resources remain below 80% utilization.
environment_requirements: Isolated performance testing environment with production-like specs.
failure_impact: High - The platform will not meet its performance NFRs, leading to a poor user experience at scale.
data_setup_complexity: High - Requires complex data generation scripts.
cleanup_requirements: Reset the performance database to a baseline state after tests.
performance_expectations: Meets or exceeds the defined NFRs.

test_description: Verify the 'Right to be Forgotten' by confirming all user data is purged from all systems after the account deletion grace period.
business_risk: Critical - Failure to comply with GDPR/CCPA can result in severe legal and financial penalties.
preconditions: A test user exists with a full profile, posts, comments, connections, and images in S3.
test_steps: 1. As the test user, initiate permanent account deletion. 2. Wait for the (accelerated) grace period to expire. 3. Verify the data purge job runs. 4. Query PostgreSQL to confirm user record, profile, posts, comments, and connections are deleted. 5. Query OpenSearch to confirm the user document is deleted. 6. Check S3 to confirm the user's uploaded images are deleted. 7. Query the deletion audit log to confirm an entry was made.
expected_result: All personally identifiable data for the user is permanently removed from all live data stores. An audit log of the deletion exists.
test_data_needs: A fully populated test user account.
tools_required: Cypress, PostgreSQL Client, OpenSearch Client, AWS CLI (for S3)
environment_requirements: Staging environment with a configurable deletion grace period.
success_criteria: 100% of specified user data is verifiably deleted from all systems.
failure_impact: Critical - Regulatory non-compliance, loss of user trust.
data_setup_complexity: High - Requires creating a user with data across all services.
cleanup_requirements: N/A - The test's purpose is cleanup.
security_considerations: The deletion process must be irreversible and complete.
performance_expectations: The deletion job should not impact live system performance.
